simulated_ratings.title: Angels and Insects
simulated_ratings.feeling: A moody Victorian intrigue with dark undercurrents is absorbing, if a touch mannered for me.

simulated_ratings.title: A Plasticine Crow
simulated_ratings.feeling: Clever fable parody, but as a brief animation it’s more amusing than affecting for me.

simulated_ratings.title: To Die For
simulated_ratings.feeling: A sharp, cold-blooded media satire with a nasty crime streak I can get behind.

simulated_ratings.title: Drowning Mona
simulated_ratings.feeling: The crime setup intrigues, but the broad, quirky humor leaves me lukewarm.

simulated_ratings.title: Bridges of Madison County, The
simulated_ratings.feeling: A quietly adult romance that feels grounded and sincere rather than schmaltzy.

simulated_ratings.title: Remains of the Day, The
simulated_ratings.feeling: Subtle, slow-burn restraint and moral stakes I respect, even at its most buttoned-up.

simulated_ratings.title: Winter in Prostokvashino
simulated_ratings.feeling: Pleasant, light animated antics, but too slight to linger.

simulated_ratings.title: Color Purple, The
simulated_ratings.feeling: An unflinching, emotionally heavy journey that rewards patience and empathy.

simulated_ratings.title: Pledge, The
simulated_ratings.feeling: Grim, methodical investigation with a weary edge—my kind of crime drama.

simulated_ratings.title: Terms of Endearment
simulated_ratings.feeling: Engaging mother–daughter push-pull, though the sentimental streak holds me at arm’s length.

simulated_ratings.title: Poison
simulated_ratings.feeling: Bold and transgressive, but the fragmented weirdness keeps me more curious than moved.

simulated_ratings.title: Heat
simulated_ratings.feeling: Taut, character-driven cops-and-robbers with real weight—thrilling and absorbing.

simulated_ratings.title: Cat Ballou
simulated_ratings.feeling: Western hijinks aren’t really my thing, and the comedy feels too broad for me.

simulated_ratings.feeling: A bruised, melancholy crime tale with propulsion and heart that really lands.

simulated_ratings.feeling: The self-help comedy angle feels thin and too sketch-like for my taste.

simulated_ratings.title: Prince of Tides, The
simulated_ratings.feeling: Earnest and polished, though the melodrama sometimes outweighs the nuance.

simulated_ratings.title: Crucible, The

simulated_ratings.title: ...And Justice for All
simulated_ratings.feeling: Legal idealism versus corruption is a vein I enjoy, and this digs in.

simulated_ratings.feeling: A neat dinner-party conceit with bite, if a bit tidy and contrived.
